title: Circuits - brightness of three light bulbs

content.description: A circuit contains three identical light bulbs, <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math>, <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"> <mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi> </math>, and <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"> <mi mathvariant="normal">Z</mi> </math>, and a switch connected to a battery of <math alttext="e m f" overflow="scroll"><mi>emf</mi></math> <math alttext="script open E" overflow="scroll"><mi>∆ê</mi></math>, as shown. The switch is initially open and bulbs <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> and <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> have equal brightness, while Bulb <math alttext="Z" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Z</mi></math> is not lit.
content.question:
What happens to the brightness of bulbs <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"> <mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi> </math> and <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> when the switch is closed?

Bulb <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math>
 Bulb <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math>

A
 Remains the same
 Becomes dimmer

B

 Remains the same

C
 Becomes brighter
 Becomes dimmer

D

 Remains the same
